FY1920.Q31: To advance scientific knowledge of the physics, chemistry, and engineering of materials through the use of Ion Beams.
FY1920.Q32: To contribute to a deeper understanding of scientific phenomena by providing a valuable experimental tool and resource of researchers at UAlbany, other educational, industry, and Federal agencies.
FY1920.Q41: The Extrion implanter was down for repairs most of the year, this affected the revenues generated. These revenues are included "additional Resources below.

FY1920.Q64: Proof of concept for at least one IP application (likely filed) by Rabi Musah on therapy that employs neutron beam was obtained using the Ion Beam Lab. Details were not provided to IBL.
FY1920.Q66: IBL is a service organization. Its employees and staff do not normally make presentations at conferences.
FY1920.Q81_4:
Expanded the customer base of outside academic and industry partners utilizing the IBL.
Current users:
UAlbany: Rabi Musah (Chem), Bill Lanford (Phys), M. Szydagis (Phys)
Academic: RPI, SUNY Poly, RIT
Industry: IBM, Intel, BMW, Materials Diagnostics, Dynamic Radiation Solutions
Federal agencies: Air Force, NASA
FY1920.Q81_5: Completed Phase 1 of the Extrion implanter redesign and rebuilding. We have gathered most of the materials needed for phase two (Covid has complicated this). Written 90% of the control software needed for phase two.
FY1920.Q81_6:
We were able to add capabilities to the facility that expanded the value of our facility to our users. 

(See details in the Goals and results section)
FY1920.Q91: To expand the usage of the IBL by designing and implementing methods of  specialized characterization work that can be performed by IBL staff for outside entities. This will expand both our research utility as well as our revenue opportunities.
FY1920.Q92:
The IBL has performed analysis work for industry partners like IBM, BMW, Intel, Nokomis and Radiation Dynamics. This work is in addition to the ever expanding list of outside universities that we have performed sample analysis for. 

These activities help concentrate research and development efforts in new and exciting fields here in the Capital District.
FY1920.Q93: We were able to increase revenue through the sale of characterization services to outside entities in spite of the downtime of the Extrion.
FY1920.Q101: To redesign and rebuild the Extrion Implant Accelerator. This refit will increase its capabilities, allowing us to expand our research utility, and simplify its use for operators which will increase its use.
FY1920.Q102:
The IBL has completed the first phase of the project which was to design and have manufactured a new high voltage power supply. The design work was done in-house and the construction was done off site.  

The path forward has been outlined and materials are being purchased in preparation for phase two.
FY1920.Q103:
The power supply has been incorporated into the system and functions as designed.

The phase two materials are almost all in-house (Covid has slowed this to a crawl) and the control software has been mostly written.
FY1920.Q104: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY1920.Q111: Expand the capabilities of the Facility to increase its utility to a more diverse customer base.
FY1920.Q112:
Reconfigure the 30 degree line to produce both high and low energy neutrons.

Designed and built a new end station on the 20 degree line to attach a cryo containment vessel to expose samples provided by outside users to simulated solar wind.

These efforts have added to the overall capabilities of the IBL facility.
FY1920.Q113:
We were able to produce thermal neutrons to facilitate testing of a compound developed by Prof Rabi Musah in the SUNY Albany Chemistry department. This research will be used to develop better methods of treating cancer using Boron Neutron Capture Therapy.

We were also able to produce high energy neutrons to create reference samples for  Prof Cecilia Levy in the SUNY Albany Physics department, This research was being conducted jointly with RPI and is part of an ongoing research project to detect Dark mater particles using geological samples. 

We were able to utilize the 20 degree line to expose samples for the US Air Force that were being analyzed by George Nelson at RIT in collaboration with Radiation Dynamics Inc.. This research will help develop the models used by the Air Force and NASA to calculate solar wind damage experienced by satellites in earth orbit.
FY1920.Q114: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY1920.Q121: The IBL is currently working to replace support systems that have exceeded their service life in an effort to lower the overall energy consumption of the facility. It is also working on installing new control systems on the Dynamitron and the Extrion to better manage the system itself and also better manage their energy consumption. These efforts fall in line with SUNY’s overall efforts to lower the its energy consumption. As a facility dedicated to the study of the natural world it is imperative that the IBL participates in its conservation.
FY1920.Q122: Some efforts have been made on this front but Staffing constraints have slowed progress.
FY1920.Q124: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY1920.Q131: Increase educational support at the IBL.
FY1920.Q132: The IBL continues to support education by providing access to the facilities in order to educate/train both graduate and undergraduate students. These efforts include graduate student training and undergraduate lab experiments to support lab classes like PHY 335.
FY1920.Q133: We now have an additional 5 grad students qualified to work at the IBL belonging to three different universities.
FY1920.Q151: The IBL has the opportunity to participate in the fields of space weather, geology, biology and material science. This would increase our research utility as well as increase our revenues.
FY1920.Q152:
The (IBL) is composed of several experimental systems that have a wide range of sizes and complexity. Each of these systems is comprised of a collection of both mechanical and electronic components, each with its own maintenance needs and operational service life. 

In order for any manufacturing or experimental system to function efficiently and extend the operational service life, each component within that system requires a well thought out, and carefully adhered to maintenance schedule. However, not adhering to the maintenance regime can, and often does lead to the premature failure of components resulting in the need for expensive repair or replacement. Unexpected component failures lead to unscheduled down time leading to the expenditure of time and capital that could otherwise be utilized to extend the capabilities of the system. 

The IBL has traditionally functioned with a contingent of personnel that ensured that the systems comprising the IBL had the care and scrutiny described above. The team consisted two to three technicians and engineers to maintain the systems and implement any upgrades or refits.  This staffing level was maintained for the forty plus years that the IBL had been in existence. 

The current contingent consists of one technician and a part-time project manager. This staffing level is no longer sufficient to meet the needs of the IBL and its continued operation, let alone expand and grow. As a result of the staffing shortfall, routine maintenance has been deferred resulting in unscheduled down time and avoidable expense. As a consequence, the time devoted to the unscheduled repairs further diminishes the time available for routine maintenance which leads to addition unscheduled downs. This spiraling degradation of the IBL’s capabilities over a decade of neglect has reached a near unsustainable level and needs to be addressed before the trend becomes unrecoverable. It goes without saying that if the day to day maintenance of the IBL systems are suffering, then the development and implementation of a Strategic Plan is impossible.
 
The current situation has already adversely affected research being performed at UAlbany as well as other Academic and Industrial affiliates. To continue on this path would eventually lead to a situation where the IBL would not be able to fulfill its Mission.
FY1920.Q153: The IBL requires at least one more additional full time Technician to help maintain the systems at the IBL. It would also benefit from a capital investment by the university to upgrade and modernize some of the aging components that are prone to failure. This would also lower our energy consumption which would be inline with the universities overall energy goals.
FY1920.Q154: Have a modernized and efficient, fully staffed facility.
FY1920.Q155: The IBL is a unique facility that has capabilities that are not available anywhere else in the world. Although it lies under ground and mostly unknown by the wider University population, its past impact on the development of our modern understanding of material science is profound. Moving forward, its expanded capabilities and practices should allow it to continue to contribute to our collective understanding of the universe in a very meaningful way. This of course is dependent on whether or not the IBL has the resources needed to first maintain, and then advance its capabilities.
